lecture_analysis.lecture_title: Ideal-Gas Processes: Isothermal, Adiabatic (Reversible), Polytropic and Free Expansion
lecture_analysis.lecture_summary: A focused review of thermodynamic properties and specific heats for ideal gases, followed by derivations and discussion of common thermodynamic processes. The lecture covers how the first and second laws apply to isothermal, reversible adiabatic (isentropic), polytropic and free expansion processes, and shows how to compute work, heat transfer and entropy change for each case. It also situates these processes on p–v diagrams and contrasts their characteristic relations.
core_topics: Thermodynamic properties (P, V, T, u, h, s)
Work and heat calculations for processes
learning_objectives: explain definitions of enthalpy and entropy and the role of specific heats for ideal gases
derive key relations linking Cp, Cv and the ideal-gas constant for an ideal gas
apply the first law to compute work and heat for isothermal, adiabatic and polytropic processes
derive process-specific relations and identify when a process is isentropic
calculate entropy change for reversible and irreversible ideal-gas processes including free expansion
interpret and compare process paths on a p–v diagram
assumed_prerequisites: familiarity with the ideal gas law

derivations.derivation_title: Reversible adiabatic (ideal gas) — relation between p, v, T and work
derivations.derivation_stub: Derive: $$p v^{\gamma}=\text{const},\quad T v^{\gamma-1}=\text{const},\quad w=\dfrac{p_1v_1-p_2v_2}{\gamma-1}$$ for a reversible adiabatic ideal gas (\(q=0\)).
steps: 1) Start: reversible adiabatic ⇒ $$\delta q_{rev}=0.$$ First law (per unit mass or per mole): $$\delta q-\delta w=du\Rightarrow 0-\delta w=du\Rightarrow -\delta w=du.$$
2) For reversible work, $$\delta w=p\,dv\,$$ (sign convention in notes leads to $$-p\,dv=du$$). For an ideal gas, $$du=C_v\,dT.$$ So
3) Use ideal-gas law $$p v = R T\quad\Rightarrow\quad p=\dfrac{R T}{v}.$$ Substitute into the differential relation:
$$-\dfrac{R T}{v}\,dv = C_v\,dT.$$
4) Rearranged (divide by RT):
$$\dfrac{C_v}{R}\dfrac{dT}{T} + \dfrac{dv}{v}=0.$$
5) Integrate between states 1 and 2:
$$\dfrac{C_v}{R}\ln\dfrac{T_2}{T_1} + \ln\dfrac{v_2}{v_1}=0\quad\Rightarrow\quad \ln\left[\left(\dfrac{T_2}{T_1}\right)^{C_v/R}\dfrac{v_2}{v_1}\right]=0.$$
6) Exponentiate and rearrange to show the T–v relation. Using $$\dfrac{R}{C_v}=\gamma-1\quad(\text{since }C_p-C_v=R,\;\gamma= C_p/C_v),$$ we get
$$T_2\,v_2^{\gamma-1}=T_1\,v_1^{\gamma-1}\quad\Rightarrow\quad T\,v^{\gamma-1}=\text{const}.$$
7) From ideal gas, multiply the previous relation by appropriate power of v to get p–v relation:
$$p v^{\gamma} = \left(\dfrac{R T}{v}\right) v^{\gamma} = R T v^{\gamma-1} = \text{const}.$$
Therefore $$p v^{\gamma}=\text{const}.$$
8) Work for a reversible adiabatic process: write $$p = C v^{-\gamma}\ (C=\text{const}).$$ Then
$$w=\int_{v_1}^{v_2} p\,dv = C\int_{v_1}^{v_2} v^{-\gamma}\,dv = \dfrac{C}{-\gamma+1}\left[v^{-\gamma+1}\right]_{v_1}^{v_2}.$$
Using $$C=p_1 v_1^{\gamma}$$ this becomes
Equivalently, with ideal-gas substitution, $$w=\dfrac{mR(T_1-T_2)}{\gamma-1}.$$

9) Internal energy change and entropy: for adiabatic reversible, $$\delta q=0\Rightarrow\Delta s=0\ (\text{isentropic}).$$ Also from first law used above, $$\Delta u = -w\ (\text{with sign convention used in notes}).$$

10) Completeness: The derivation shown on pages 3–4 is essentially complete for an ideal gas with constant heat capacities (Cp,Cv constant). The notes assume constant Cv and ideal-gas behaviour; sign convention for work is the one used in the notes (gives -p dv = du). No boundary-condition integrals are missing for this derivation.

derivations.derivation_title: Entropy change for an ideal gas (general expression)
derivations.derivation_stub: Derive: $$\Delta s = C_v\ln\dfrac{T_2}{T_1} + R\ln\dfrac{v_2}{v_1} = C_p\ln\dfrac{T_2}{T_1} - R\ln\dfrac{p_2}{p_1}.$$
steps: 1) Start from differential entropy for a reversible change: $$ds = \dfrac{\delta q_{rev}}{T}.$$ For an ideal gas with constant heat capacities, express dq in terms of dT and dv (or dp):
2) Using internal energy relation and Maxwell-type manipulations leads to the integrated forms:
$$\Delta s = C_v\ln\dfrac{T_2}{T_1} + R\ln\dfrac{v_2}{v_1},$$
and, using $$p v = R T$$, equivalently
$$\Delta s = C_p\ln\dfrac{T_2}{T_1} - R\ln\dfrac{p_2}{p_1}.$$

derivations.derivation_title: Isothermal process (ideal gas): work and entropy
derivations.derivation_stub: Show for isothermal (T constant): $$p v = \text{const},\quad w = p_1 v_1 \ln\dfrac{v_2}{v_1},\quad q=w,\quad \Delta s = R\ln\dfrac{v_2}{v_1}.$$
steps: 1) For isothermal T1=T2 and ideal gas, $$p_1 v_1 = p_2 v_2 = m R T.$$ Thus $$p v = \text{const}.$$
2) Work done: $$w=\int_{v_1}^{v_2} p\,dv = \int_{v_1}^{v_2} \dfrac{C}{v}\,dv = C\ln\dfrac{v_2}{v_1} = p_1 v_1 \ln\dfrac{v_2}{v_1}.$$
3) Energy: for ideal gas $$\Delta u=0\Rightarrow q=w.$$ Entropy change for the reversible isothermal process:
$$\Delta s = \dfrac{q_{rev}}{T} = R\ln\dfrac{v_2}{v_1} = -R\ln\dfrac{p_2}{p_1}.$$

derivations.derivation_title: Cp, Cv relation and definition of adiabatic index
steps: 1) Definitions: $$C_p\equiv\left(\dfrac{\partial h}{\partial T}\right)_p,\quad C_v\equiv\left(\dfrac{\partial u}{\partial T}\right)_v.$$ For an ideal gas h=u+pv and p v = R T.
2) Differentiate and combine to get $$C_p - C_v = R.$$ Define $$\gamma\equiv C_p/C_v$$ and rearrange to obtain $$C_v=\dfrac{R}{\gamma-1},\; C_p=\dfrac{\gamma R}{\gamma-1}.$$

derivations.derivation_title: Work and relations for a polytropic process (pv^n=const)
derivations.derivation_stub: For polytropic index n: $$p v^{n}=\text{const},\quad w=\dfrac{p_1 v_1 - p_2 v_2}{n-1},\quad \Delta u = C_v\Delta T,\;\Delta h = C_p\Delta T.$$
steps: 1) Polytropic definition: $$p v^{n}=\text{const}.$$ Using ideal-gas relations one can write $$T v^{n-1}=\text{const},\; p\sim T^{n/(n-1)},\; T\sim p^{(n-1)/n}.$$
2) Work for a polytropic process (n≠1): with $$p=C v^{-n}$$ then
3) Internal and enthalpy changes use constant heat capacities: $$\Delta u=C_v\Delta T,\quad \Delta h=C_p\Delta T.$$ Entropy: $$\Delta s = C_p\ln\dfrac{T_2}{T_1} - R\ln\dfrac{p_2}{p_1}.$$

derivations.derivation_stub: For free expansion into vacuum (no work, no heat): $$q=0,\;w=0,\;\Delta u=0\Rightarrow\Delta T=0\Rightarrow\Delta h=0;\;\Delta s=R\ln\dfrac{v_2}{v_1}.$$
steps: 1) Free expansion: no heat exchange and no boundary work so $$q=0,\; w=0.$$ For ideal gas, $$\Delta u=0\Rightarrow \Delta T=0\Rightarrow \Delta h=0.$$
2) Initial and final states satisfy ideal-gas law, but because the process is irreversible entropy increases. Using a reversible path between the same states (isothermal) gives the entropy change
$$\Delta s = -R\ln\dfrac{p_2}{p_1} = R\ln\dfrac{v_2}{v_1}.$$

conceptual_questions.question: For an ideal gas undergoing a reversible isothermal expansion from V1 to V2 (T constant), which of the following statements is correct?
conceptual_questions.explanation: For an ideal gas u depends only on T, so ΔU = 0 for an isothermal process. By the first law q = w (heat absorbed equals work done). The entropy change is ΔS = R ln(V2/V1), not zero unless V2 = V1.

conceptual_questions.question: Which value of the polytropic exponent n corresponds to a reversible adiabatic (isentropic) process for an ideal gas?
conceptual_questions.explanation: A reversible adiabatic (no heat) process for an ideal gas obeys p v^γ = constant, where γ = Cp/Cv. Thus the polytropic exponent equals γ for the adiabatic case.

conceptual_questions.question: Which statement correctly describes a free (Joule) expansion of an ideal gas into vacuum?

options.text: q = 0, w = 0, ΔU = 0 and entropy increases (ΔS > 0)
q = 0, w = 0, ΔU = 0 and entropy change ΔS = 0

conceptual_questions.explanation: In free expansion there is no heat or work exchange (q = 0, w = 0). For an ideal gas ΔU depends only on T and remains zero (no temperature change). The process is irreversible, so entropy of the gas increases (ΔS > 0).
